headline: Evergy (EVRG): Reassessing Valuation After a Recent Pullback in a Strong Year for the Stock
summary: Evergy (EVRG) has been quietly grinding higher this year, and with the stock pulling back about 4% over the past month, investors are starting to reassess whether this steady utility is offering fresh value. See our latest analysis for Evergy. The recent dip comes after a strong run, with a year to date share price return of 17.57 percent and a five year total shareholder return of 65.67 percent, suggesting momentum is still broadly constructive rather than exhausted. If Evergy has you...

headline: Is Evergy Still Worth Considering After Its Strong 2024 Share Price Run?
summary: Wondering if Evergy at around $72 a share is still worth buying after its run higher, or if the easy money has already been made? You are not alone, and that is exactly what this breakdown will dig into. Despite a recent pullback of about 1.8% over the last week and 4.2% over the last month, the stock is still up 17.6% year to date and 22.6% over the past year, with 3 year and 5 year gains of 30.2% and 65.7% respectively. That mix of short term softness and strong longer term returns is...

headline: What Analysts Think Is Changing the Story for Evergy Investors
summary: Evergy's latest narrative update sees its fair value estimate nudged slightly lower to $83.59 per share, even as the discount rate and long term revenue growth assumptions remain largely intact. Analysts now expect revenue to grow at roughly 5.67% a year, a modest step down that balances stronger regulatory visibility and sector tailwinds with lingering questions around near term demand and execution. As these shifts in expectations continue to unfold, stay tuned to learn how you can track...

headline: AI boom brings flood of debt to ultrasafe market
summary: Bond sales by US utilities grew 19% this year to a record $158 billion, funding rampant growth in power demand driven by the artificial-intelligence boom.  A lot more is coming: electric companies are expected to spend more than $1.1 trillion on power plants, substations, and other grid infrastructure over the next five years, according to industry group Edison Electric Institute, up about 44% from the previous period.
